intro: Mentha arvensis subsp. piperascens, commonly known as field mint, is a perennial herb native to temperate regions of Europe and Asia. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring square stems and opposite, serrated leaves that are aromatic when crushed. The plant produces small, pale blue to purple flowers in whorled clusters, which bloom from late spring to early autumn. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in meadows, pastures, and along streambanks. Its essential oils contain menthol and other compounds, making it useful in traditional medicine and as a flavoring agent.
